title: Phrases
description: This lessons introduces an essential building block of te reo Māori: the phrase.

elements.content:
In te reo Māori, like in English, a sentence is a grammatical unit which represents a complete statement, question, command or exclamation. You're probably pretty familiar with sentences, because they're something you have to keep in mind when writing in English and determining where to put the full stop to separate complex ideas into separate elements.

Sentences are made up of clauses, which most people spend less time being conscious of. They're the building blocks of sentences which need to contain two key ingredients:

* **A subject**: This is what the clause is about. In the clause "dinner was delicious", *dinner* is the subject. In the clause "the cat meowed", *the* *cat* is the subject.

* **The predicate**: This is what you're wanting to say about the subject. In the clause "dinner was delicious", the predicate is "*was delicious*". In the clause "the cat meowed", the predicate is "*meowed*". It's the information about the subject which the clause is designed to communicate. In English, the predicate must contain a verb, but in te reo Māori, that's not always the case.
An example of a clause with its subject and predicate in te reo Māori might be:

translations.He nui te kai: There is a lot of food
translations.He nui te tina: There is a lot of dinner

elements.content:
The sentence "John went to the market to buy milk" is made up of two clauses:

* "John went to the market" is the main clause; it's what the sentence is about. The subject is *John* and the predicate is *went to the market.*

* "to buy milk" is a dependent clause, which expands on and adds context to the main clause. The subject is still *John* and doesn't need to be explicitly stated where it's understood to be the same as the subject of the main clause. The predicate is "to buy milk".
An example of a sentence with two clauses in te reo Māori might look like:

options: I haere a Hone ki te mākete
I haere a Hone ki te whare pukapuka
I haere a Hone ki te puna kaukau
ki te whakahoki i tētahi pukapuka

translations.I haere a Hone ki te mākete ki te hoko h: Hone went to the market to buy (chicken) eggs
translations.I haere a Hone ki te mākete ki te hoko m: Hone went to the market to buy milk
translations.I haere a Hone ki te mākete ki te whakah: Hone went to the market to return a book
translations.I haere a Hone ki te mākete ki te kaukau: Hone went to the market to swim
translations.I haere a Hone ki te whare pukapuka ki t: Hone went to the library to buy (chicken) eggs
Hone went to the library to buy milk
Hone went to the library to return a book
Hone went to the library to swim
translations.I haere a Hone ki te puna kaukau ki te h: Hone went to the pool to buy (chicken) eggs
Hone went to the pool to buy milk
translations.I haere a Hone ki te puna kaukau ki te w: Hone went to the pool to return a book
translations.I haere a Hone ki te puna kaukau ki te k: Hone went to the pool to swim

elements.content:
In English, the next smallest unit of grammar after the clause is the word. However, te reo Māori has another grammatical unit which is the building block of the clause. This building block is called the **phrase**.

The exercises on this website will focus on the phrase a lot as these lessons are based around the idea that understanding **the phrase is the key to being able to parse and analyse sentences in Māori.**

In Let's Learn Māori, Bruce Biggs notes: The phrase, not the word, is the unit of Maori speech that must be emphasised in learning. It is the natural grammatical unit of the language, and even more importantly, it is the natural pause unit of speech.
A phrase can be broken down into three components.

## New Text Content

Add your content here.

It must always have a main word which is called the **nucleus**. This is generally a noun, verb or pronoun. These types of words all belong to the class *[[ref\|base words\|tumu]]* or {{tumu}} (sometimes called {{kupu kiko}} or content words) and they contribute the central meaning to the phrase.

The nucleus can optionally have words **preceding** it and **following** it.

These words which flank the nucleus are said to be in the "peripheries" and are technically referred to as the *preposed periphery* and the *postposed periphery*. We'll return to using this terminology in the more advanced lessons, but for now we're just calling them *preceding words* and *following words* and introducing the technical words so you know what they are if you see them somewhere else.

In the same way the nucleus must contain a base word, the preceding and following words must be [[ref\|particles\|punga]] or {{punga}}. Some particles can only precede the nucleus, while others can only follow it.

Particles are the glue which hold the sentences together, communicating additional context such as:

* whether the sentence is past, present or future tense

* whether an activity being described is ongoing or has ended

* whether the sentence is about a specific object such as "the cat" or is less specific such as "a cat".

* whether a possessive relationship is being described such as "my car", "the student's work" or "your cat".

For example, in the sentence {{e oma ana te rāpeti}} (the rabbit is running) there are two phrases: {{e oma ana}} and {{te rāpeti}}.

In the first phrase, {{e oma ana}}, the nucleus is the word {{oma}} which means run.

{{E}} and {{ana}} are a pair of *[[ref\|particles\|punga]]* which contribute additional context, in this case communicating that the situation being described (the running of the rabbit) is ongoing.

This is an example of a base word, flanked by two particles. If we instead changed this phrase from {{e oma ana}} to {{i oma}}, the particle {{i}} would communicate that the running was something that happened in the past.

The second phrase in this sentence is {{te rāpeti}} which means "the rabbit". {{Rāpeti}} is the nucleus of the phrase and it is preceded by the word {{te}} which is called the *[[ref\|definite article\|putohu]]*, roughly translatable in this sentence to "the". There isn't a following word in this phrase, because the preceding and following parts of the phrase are optional. However, we could modify the phrase to be {{te rāpeti nei}} using the particle {{nei}} which signifies that we're talking about something near the speaker and changes the meaning to be "this rabbit (near me)" instead of "the rabbit."

You can use the Sentence Analyser below to review the sentence, breaking it down into different elements for review. For this example, the Sentence Analyser will show you the full sentence or the individual phrases, but future uses of the Sentence Analyser might also break sentences down into clauses or words.

sentence.explanation:
This is a simple verbal sentence with a single clause. 

The rabbit is the subject of the sentence and "is running" is the predicate.

phrase.explanation: This is a verb phrase ([[ref|kīanga tūmahi|kiianga-tuumahi]]) with the [[ref|continuous tense marker|pumahi]] {{e...ana}} and the verb {{oma}}. As the predicate, it communicates that the subject is running.
This is a proper noun phrase ([[ref|kīanga tūingoa|kiianga-tuuingoa]]) with the definite article {{te}} and the proper noun {{rāpeti}}. It is the subject of the sentence.

elements.content: The nucleus of a phrase almost always contains one or more [[ref\|tumu\|tumu]] (base words). In cases where there is more than one base, one of the bases is the **head** of the phrase and provides the main context for the phrase, with the other bases acting as modifiers on that.

## New Text Content

Add your content here.

In the sentence above, the word [[word|waka|w-waka]] is what the sentence about and the other words are used to specify the type of waka we're talking about: {{rererangi}} (aircraft), {{tūroro}} (to be sick) or {{topaki}} (to hover).

Although there are many ways of describing different phrase types, they can broadly be broken up into [[ref\|kīanga tūmahi\|kiianga-tuumahi]] (verb phrases), [[ref\|kīanga tūingoa\|kiianga-tuuingoa]] (noun phrases) and [[ref\|kīanga pūhono\|kiianga-puuhono]] (prepositional phrases).

Verb phrases are any phrase where the head word functions as a verb. They include [[ref\|pūmahi\|pumahi]] (verbal particles) and commonly act as the predicate of a clause.

Noun phrases are any phrase where the head word functions as a noun. They include [[ref\|pūmau\|pumau]] (determiners) as particles and commonly act as the subject of a clause.

Prepositional phrases are phrases which are introduced by [[ref\|pūhono\|puhono]] (prepositions). They are used for a variety of purposes to add additional context to a clause.

elements.content: That's it for our quick introduction to the phrase. We'll be exploring the phrase in a lot more detail as we progress (most of the lessons will be built around phrases), but the intent for this exercise is to introduce what phrases look like so that when future exercises use them as a key way to scaffold your understanding of Māori sentences, they're not totally new to you.
